messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Brett Neumeier

> > Obviously, one test can belong to several tests.
>
> ...several groups(?)

Oops, yes, right.

> > @Test(groups = { "check-in", "functional", "database" })
>
> Or you can use marker interfaces to the same purpose:
>
> public class FooTest implements NeedsDatabaseTest,
> FunctionalTest { ... }

Right, but I think this hack is similar in nature to prefixing your methods
with "test": it's an artefact from the past when we were abusing the Java
type system to cram more information into classes and methods.

Annotations are a cleaner way to do this and they don't interfere with the
type system.

> How are annotations superior to just using interfaces like that?

Did I answer your question?

Actually, I think the interface marker hack is worse than prefixing your
methods with "tests", because it actually changes the type of your class for
no benefit to your business logic or future readers of your code. This kind
of information should not appear in JavaDoc nor with javap: it should be
completely hidden and available only to the tool that will use it.

Also, you can quickly see how using this trick to implement groups of tests
can lead to a combinatorial explosion of interfaces and to classes that
implement five or ten different interfaces... Not very clean.
